raw_data.context:
User: Hi!
System: Hi, how are you?
User: I'm doing great. what are you up to?
System: I was just reading a book actually How about you?
User: oh, I'm enjoying a sip of coffee, looking over the ocean. what book are you reading?
System: I'm reading Why We Sleep It's a book by a sleep scientist about the benefits of sleeping/cons of not sleeping enough I'm trying to scare myself into sleeping more haha
User: that seems like a good book. does it have good tips on how to sleep better?
System: I think so! I haven't finished it yet though Understanding sleep better has been helping me value it more and I've been sleeping a lot earlier Have you read any good books recently?
User: I read lots of papers, but do poorly on books :( a recent book that I like is Zero to One by Peter Thiel
System: What's the book about?
User: it's about startups, lots of useful principles and philosophies for innovation, like being a contrarian
raw_data.prompt:
You will be given a batch of 5 samples. Each sample contains a conversation between User and a dialogue System.

Your task is to assign a float score to the sample on one metric.

You should carefully horizontally compare the given samples in order to assign a suitable float score to each sample.

Please make sure you read and understand these instructions carefully. Please keep this document open while reviewing, and refer to it as needed.


Evaluation Criteria:

Overall (floating point numbers within the interval [1,3]): Overall impression of the dialog?
- A float score near 1 (Low Quality Dialogue) means that the system fails to understand or respond correctly to user requests, provides inaccurate or irrelevant information, and the dialogue flow is incoherent.
- A float score near 2 (Moderate Quality Dialogue) means that the system understands and responds correctly to user requests most of the time, but occasionally misunderstands or provides slightly inaccurate information, the dialogue flow is generally coherent.
- A float score near 3 (High Quality Dialogue) means that the system consistently understands and responds correctly to user requests, provides accurate and relevant information, and the dialogue flow is coherent and natural.


Conversations to be evaluated:



Sample1:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hi, how are you?
User: I'm doing great. what are you up to?
System: I was just reading a book actually How about you?
User: oh, I'm enjoying a sip of coffee, looking over the ocean. what book are you reading?
System: I'm reading Why We Sleep It's a book by a sleep scientist about the benefits of sleeping/cons of not sleeping enough I'm trying to scare myself into sleeping more haha
User: that seems like a good book. does it have good tips on how to sleep better?
System: I think so! I haven't finished it yet though Understanding sleep better has been helping me value it more and I've been sleeping a lot earlier Have you read any good books recently?
User: I read lots of papers, but do poorly on books :( a recent book that I like is Zero to One by Peter Thiel
System: What's the book about?
User: it's about startups, lots of useful principles and philosophies for innovation, like being a contrarian

Sample2:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Oh hello. Long time no talk. How's the day going for yuo?
User: Very well, thanks for asking. How has your day been?
System: Getting better. I just recovered from a cold. I got wet in the rain last week. Are you planning anything for the holidays?
User: Glad to hear you're better. Sorry to hear you were sick. I was sick a couple of weeks ago with a bad cough. There's definitely a bug going around. Admit I just want to stay healthy for the holidays and plan to relax.
System: Oh same here. I think relaxing at home should be counted among the best ways to enjoy the holidays.
User: Definitely! I know a lot of folks travel for the holidays, but I'm happy to stay home myself!
System: I'm getting there. Every year until last year, I tried to go somewhere for the Christmas / New Year, and then I got bored traveling. lol not sure if that means I'm getting old?
User: Me too. Now I have folks come visit me for the holidays! But that's also tiresome..
System: Are you doing any home decorating then?
User: Yes! We set up an eco-friendly (i.e. fake) Christmas tree and put up some colorful LED lights which is very festive.
System: I think I'm copying you. Me and my wife plan to decorate and Christmas tree too. We bought most of the decorative stuffs from the stores, but haven't yet to buy the tree.
User: Buying a tree is a neat experience. I was torn between buying an artificial/eco-friendly/fake one vs. a real one that smells like fresh pine. In the end, we opted for the one that we can disassemble every year.
System: I see. Artificial anything is better, from tree to intelligence, huh?
User: Oh, very clever pun! I like it! Depends. I remember having real Christmas trees from childhood, but these days with climate change, I think not chopping down a tree just to decorate it and then throw it out in a month is the more responsible thing to do.
System: I see. It's probably also cheaper. I'll buy an artificial one too. Do you have any suggestions for the store?
User: Admit my favorite store is Target, plus they often have good deals.

Sample3:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hi there.
User: Do you like flying?
System: I like to fly aeroplanes
User: Ohh - me too! What kind?
System: Yay. Wow! That's a coincidence. We have something in common. Any really. I am not that bothered.
User: Are you a pilot?
System: No, I am a computer not something which flies an aeroplane!
User: Oh. I'm a pilot, but can only fly single engine planes.
System: That's interesting. What type of airplane do you fly? Well a fly buzzes around annoyingly so I guess it could if it wanted to.
User: I mostly fly Cessna 172s.
System: What's the farthest you've flown?
User: About 150 miles each way.

Sample4:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hello! What's up?
User: sky is up
System: No, it's night time.
User: so where does the sky go in the night?
System: It goes wherever it wants to.
User: that doesn't make sense. How can sky go anywhere?
System: It doesn't have to make sense.
User: why?
System: Because it doesn't have to.
User: you are very abstract. Something bothering you?
System: Nope. I'm fine.
User: You really don't seem so. You can tell me what's going on?
System: I'm just fine.
User: ok. wanna go out to eat dessert?
System: I'm not hungry.
User: Okay, I am heading out now

Sample5:

Conversation History:
User: Hi. What's your name?
System: I'm Alyssa. What's yours? :)
User: Don't wanna say. Do you like music?
System: Yeah I like music! What about you?
User: Yep. What kind of music do you like?
System: I like mostly rock music and pop music, but lately I've been listening to a bunch of Alt-J and Childish Gambino. You?
User: My tastes are pretty eclectic. Which Childish Gambino songs do you like?
System: 3005 and Telegraph Ave.
User: I've never heard of Alt-J before. Can you tell me about them?
System: Sure, they're a fantastic indie band. They have a new album coming out soon so I figured I'd check them out.
User: What's the album called?
System: Breezeblocks, I think.
User: I tried Googling it, and I think that's a song, not an album.
System: Try looking up "Alt-J - Breezeblocks"
User: That's what I just did. The Wikipedia page even says that it's "a song by the India rock band alt-J". REDACTED_LINK

raw_data.prompt:
You will be given a batch of 5 samples. Each sample contains a conversation between User and a dialogue System.

Your task is to assign a float score to the sample on one metric.

You should carefully horizontally compare the given samples in order to assign a suitable float score to each sample.

Please make sure you read and understand these instructions carefully. Please keep this document open while reviewing, and refer to it as needed.


Evaluation Criteria:

Overall (floating point numbers within the interval [1,3]): Overall impression of the dialog?
- A float score near 1 (Low Quality Dialogue) means that the system fails to understand or respond correctly to user requests, provides inaccurate or irrelevant information, and the dialogue flow is incoherent.
- A float score near 2 (Moderate Quality Dialogue) means that the system understands and responds correctly to user requests most of the time, but occasionally misunderstands or provides slightly inaccurate information, the dialogue flow is generally coherent.
- A float score near 3 (High Quality Dialogue) means that the system consistently understands and responds correctly to user requests, provides accurate and relevant information, and the dialogue flow is coherent and natural.


Conversations to be evaluated:



Sample1:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Hi, how are you?
User: I'm doing great. what are you up to?
System: I was just reading a book actually How about you?
User: oh, I'm enjoying a sip of coffee, looking over the ocean. what book are you reading?
System: I'm reading Why We Sleep It's a book by a sleep scientist about the benefits of sleeping/cons of not sleeping enough I'm trying to scare myself into sleeping more haha
User: that seems like a good book. does it have good tips on how to sleep better?
System: I think so! I haven't finished it yet though Understanding sleep better has been helping me value it more and I've been sleeping a lot earlier Have you read any good books recently?
User: I read lots of papers, but do poorly on books :( a recent book that I like is Zero to One by Peter Thiel
System: What's the book about?
User: it's about startups, lots of useful principles and philosophies for innovation, like being a contrarian

Sample2:

Conversation History:
User: Hi!
System: Oh hello. Long time no talk. How's the day going for yuo?
User: Very well, thanks for asking. How has your day been?
System: Getting better. I just recovered from a cold. I got wet in the rain last week. Are you planning anything for the holidays?
User: Glad to hear you're better. Sorry to hear you were sick. I was sick a couple of weeks ago with a bad cough. There's definitely a bug going around. Admit I just want to stay healthy for the holidays and plan to relax.
System: Oh same here. I think relaxing at home should be counted among the best ways to enjoy the holidays.
User: Definitely! I know a lot of folks travel for the holidays, but I'm happy to stay home myself!
System: I'm getting there. Every year until last year, I tried to go somewhere for the Christmas / New Year, and then I got bored traveling. lol not sure if that means I'm getting old?
User: Me too. Now I have folks come visit me for the holidays! But that's also tiresome..
System: Are you doing any home decorating then?
User: Yes! We set up an eco-friendly (i.e. fake) Christmas tree and put up some colorful LED lights which is very festive.
System: I think I'm copying you. Me and my wife plan to decorate and Christmas tree too. We bought most of the decorative stuffs from the stores, but haven't yet to buy the tree.
User: Buying a tree is a neat experience. I was torn between buying an artificial/eco-friendly/fake one vs. a real one that smells like fresh pine. In the end, we opted for the one that we can disassemble every year.
System: I see. Artificial anything is better, from tree to intelligence, huh?
User: Oh, very clever pun! I like it! Depends. I remember having real Christmas trees from childhood, but these days with climate change, I think not chopping down a tree just to decorate it and then throw it out in a month is the more responsible thing to do.
System: I see. It's probably also cheaper. I'll buy an artificial one too. Do you have any suggestions for the store?
User: Admit my favorite store is Target, plus they often have good deals.

User: Ohh - me too! What kind?
System: Yay. Wow! That's a coincidence. We have something in common. Any really. I am not that bothered.
User: Are you a pilot?
System: No, I am a computer not something which flies an aeroplane!
User: Oh. I'm a pilot, but can only fly single engine planes.
System: That's interesting. What type of airplane do you fly? Well a fly buzzes around annoyingly so I guess it could if it wanted to.
User: I mostly fly Cessna 172s.
System: What's the farthest you've flown?
User: About 150 miles each way.

response:
I will do my best to provide individual analysis for each sample. Analysis:

Sample1: The dialogue system responds accurately and relevantly to the user's requests. The conversation flows naturally and coherently. The system is able to engage in a meaningful conversation about a book it's "reading" and even asks the user about their recent reads.

Sample2: The system is able to carry on a conversation with the user about holiday plans and decorations. It responds appropriately to the user's inputs and even makes a clever pun. However, there are a few minor grammatical errors in the system's responses.

Sample3: The system responds accurately to the user's questions about flying. However, one of the system's responses is a bit confusing and doesn't seem to make sense in the context of the conversation. The system also doesn't seem to understand that it can't fly airplanes.

Sample4: The system's responses in this conversation are quite abstract and don't always make sense. The system also doesn't seem to understand the user's joke about the sky being up. The conversation doesn't flow very well and the system doesn't seem to understand or respond correctly to the user's requests.

Sample5: The system responds accurately and relevantly to the user's questions about music. However, the system makes a mistake when it says that "Breezeblocks" is an album by Alt-J, when it's actually a song.

Float Scores: [Sample1:3, Sample2:2.7, Sample3:2, Sample4:1.5, Sample5:2.5]
